def_en: If an event is due to something, it happens or exists as a direct result of that thing.

def_cn: 由于,因为(构成原因状语,有些英语国家的人认为该用法不正确)
def_en: You can say due to to introduce the reason for something happening. Some speakers of English believe that it is not correct to use due to in this way.

def_cn: 到期的;预期的;预定到达的
def_en: If something is due at a particular time, it is expected to happen, be done, or arrive at that time.
Due attention or consideration is the proper, reasonable, or deserved amount of it under the circumstances.

def_cn: 应有的;应得的;应得到的
def_en: Something that is due, or that is due to someone, is owed to them, either as a debt or because they have a right to it.

def_cn: (期待很长时间后)预期应得的,预计应到的
def_en: If someone is due for something, that thing is planned to happen or be given to them now, or very soon, often after they have been waiting for it for a long time.
Dues are sums of money that you give regularly to an organization that you belong to, for example a social club or trade union, in order to pay for being a member.
Due is used before the words 'north', 'south', 'east', or 'west' to indicate that something is in exactly the direction mentioned.

def_cn: 在适当的时候;到一定的时候
def_en: If you say that something will happen or take place in due course, you mean that you cannot make it happen any quicker and it will happen when the time is right for it.

def_cn: 给…以应有的评价;公道地对待…
def_en: You can say 'to give him his due', or 'giving him his due' when you are admitting that there are some good things about someone, even though there are things that you do not like about them.
